title: Numbers Chapter 24 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Numbers chapter 24 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Numbers Chapter 24 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Numbers Chapter 24.

questions.question: What did Balaam do when he saw that it pleased the LORD to bless Israel?
options: He set his face toward the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: He set his face toward the wilderness
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:1 says Balaam went not to seek enchantments but set his face toward the wilderness.

questions.question: What came upon Balaam when he lifted up his eyes and saw Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: The spirit of God
questions.explanation: According to Numbers 24:2, the spirit of God came upon Balaam when he saw Israel.

questions.question: How did Balaam describe Israel's tents in his parable?
questions.correctAnswer: Goodly
questions.explanation: In Numbers 24:5, Balaam says, 'How goodly are thy tents, O Jacob, and thy tabernacles, O Israel!'

questions.question: According to Numbers 24:7, how is Israel's king described in relation to Agag?
questions.correctAnswer: Higher than Agag
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:7 states, 'his king shall be higher than Agag, and his kingdom shall be exalted.'

questions.question: What strength is Israel compared to in Numbers 24:8?
questions.correctAnswer: The strength of an unicorn
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:8 compares Israel's strength to that of an unicorn.

questions.question: Who was angry with Balaam for blessing Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Balak
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:10 tells us that Balak's anger was kindled against Balaam because he blessed Israel instead of cursing them.

questions.question: What did Balaam say he could not go beyond?
questions.correctAnswer: The commandment of the LORD
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:13 states Balaam cannot go beyond the commandment of the LORD to do either good or bad of his own mind.

questions.question: What did Balaam say would come out of Jacob in the latter days?
questions.correctAnswer: A Star and a Sceptre
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:17 predicts 'there shall come a Star out of Jacob, and a Sceptre shall rise out of Israel.'

questions.question: Which nation was said to perish forever according to Balaam's prophecy?
questions.correctAnswer: Amalek
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:20 says Amalek's latter end shall be that he perish forever.

questions.question: What is said about the Kenites' dwelling place?
options: Strong and put nest in a rock
questions.correctAnswer: Strong and put nest in a rock
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:21 states the Kenites have a strong dwelling place and put their nest in a rock.

questions.question: True or False: Balaam was promoted to great honor by Balak as Balaam wished.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:11 says Balak thought to promote Balaam to great honor, but the LORD kept him back from honor.

questions.question: True or False: Balaam said he would speak only what the LORD says.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: According to Numbers 24:13, Balaam commits to speak only what the LORD commands.

questions.question: True or False: Balak was pleased with Balaam's blessings of Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:10 shows Balak's anger because Balaam blessed Israel instead of cursing them.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Numbers 24:9: 'He couched, he lay down as a ____, and as a great lion: who shall stir him up?'
questions.correctAnswer: lion
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:9 uses the imagery of a lion: 'He couched, he lay down as a lion, and as a great lion.'

questions.question: Complete the verse from Numbers 24:24: 'And ships shall come from the coast of ____, and shall afflict Asshur, and shall afflict Eber.'
questions.correctAnswer: Chittim
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:24 says ships shall come from the coast of Chittim to afflict Asshur and Eber.

medium.title: Numbers Chapter 24 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Numbers Chapter 24 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with obedience and wants to know how to discern God's will. Based on Numbers 24, what biblical truth would you share?
options: One must follow God's command strictly, not acting on personal will
Seek enchantments and signs to determine right action
Act according to what seems beneficial regardless of God's word
Ignore God's word if the reward is great
questions.correctAnswer: One must follow God's command strictly, not acting on personal will
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:13 shows Balaam stating he cannot go beyond the commandment of the LORD to do good or bad of his own mind, highlighting the importance of obedience to God's word over personal desires. This teaches faith and trust in God’s instructions.

questions.question: How does Numbers 24 teach us about humility and contentment when facing opposition or disappointment?
options: Accept that God's plans may prevent personal promotion or honor
React with anger and curse those who oppose you
Give up on faith when plans fail
questions.correctAnswer: Accept that God's plans may prevent personal promotion or honor
questions.explanation: In Numbers 24:11, Balak acknowledges that the LORD kept Balaam from honor, which teaches believers humility and contentment with God's sovereign plan even when personal advancement is withheld.

questions.question: A believer is encouraged to pray for others. How does Balaam's blessing of Israel in Numbers 24 illustrate the power of blessing and intercession?
options: Blessing others brings God’s favor and protection
Blessing is only effective if one is a prophet
Cursing enemies is preferable to blessing them
Blessing has no real spiritual impact
questions.correctAnswer: Blessing others brings God’s favor and protection
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:9 says, 'Blessed is he that blesseth thee, and cursed is he that curseth thee,' showing the spiritual power and blessing that comes from praying well for others.

questions.question: How does Numbers 24 teach about trusting God’s protection and strength in daily life and work?
options: God gives strength likened to a unicorn and protection like a lion
One must rely only on personal strength and plans
Strength comes from wealth and political power
Trust in human alliances rather than God
questions.correctAnswer: God gives strength likened to a unicorn and protection like a lion
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:8-9 describes God's provision of strength and protection to Israel, encouraging believers to trust God's power in their daily endeavors and challenges.

questions.question: When facing trials or opposition, what does Numbers 24 teach about perseverance and faith?
options: Trust God will ultimately exalt and protect His people
Avoid faith and rely on human strength
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God will ultimately exalt and protect His people
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:7 states that Israel’s king shall be exalted and his kingdom raised, teaching believers to persevere in faith, trusting God’s ultimate victory in trials.

questions.question: What biblical virtue does Balaam’s refusal to curse Israel, despite being paid, teach us?
options: Integrity and obedience to God above wealth
Manipulation of God's word for personal gain
questions.correctAnswer: Integrity and obedience to God above wealth
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:13 reveals Balaam’s commitment to speak only what the LORD commands, illustrating the importance of integrity and obedience over material gain.

questions.question: A believer is learning to share God’s promises with others. How does Balaam’s prophecy about the coming 'Star out of Jacob' encourage evangelism?
options: There is a coming Savior who will triumph over enemies
Only priests should share spiritual messages
questions.correctAnswer: There is a coming Savior who will triumph over enemies
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:17 speaks of a Star out of Jacob and a Sceptre from Israel, symbolizing the Messiah, encouraging believers to share the hope and victory found in Christ.

questions.question: How does Numbers 24 teach us about the importance of spiritual discernment through prayer and devotion?
options: The spirit of God comes upon those who seek Him sincerely
Enchantment and divination are the best ways to know God’s will
questions.correctAnswer: The spirit of God comes upon those who seek Him sincerely
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:2 shows the spirit of God coming upon Balaam when he lifted his eyes and saw Israel, emphasizing the need for sincere devotion and openness to God’s Spirit.

questions.question: True or False: Balaam’s vision and prophecy in Numbers 24 came from seeking enchantments and divination as usual.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:1 states Balaam did not seek enchantments this time because he saw the LORD was pleased to bless Israel, showing reliance on God rather than occult practices.

questions.question: True or False: Balak was pleased with Balaam’s blessings on Israel and rewarded him richly.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:10-11 records Balak’s anger because Balaam blessed Israel instead of cursing them and told him to flee, indicating displeasure rather than reward.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Numbers 24:5 describes Israel’s tents as being how? "How goodly are thy tents, O _____, and thy tabernacles, O Israel!"
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:5 specifically praises the tents of Jacob, highlighting the beauty and order of Israel’s dwelling, teaching appreciation for God’s blessings on family and community.

questions.question: How does Numbers 24 encourage believers to practice generosity and stewardship in light of God’s blessings?
options: God’s abundant blessings call for faithful stewardship and sharing
Hoard wealth as proof of God’s favor
questions.correctAnswer: God’s abundant blessings call for faithful stewardship and sharing
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:7 speaks of Israel’s seed being in many waters, symbolizing abundance, encouraging believers to respond with generosity and stewardship.

questions.question: According to Numbers 24, what is a biblical approach to dealing with enemies and opposition?
options: Trust God to defeat enemies rather than cursing or retaliation
Ignore God and fight using human schemes
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to defeat enemies rather than cursing or retaliation
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:8-9 shows God’s power to break the bones of enemies and bless those who bless Israel, teaching reliance on God’s justice rather than personal retaliation.

questions.question: How does Numbers 24 teach about the role of spiritual vision in personal devotion and leadership?
options: Spiritual vision comes from hearing God and seeing His works with eyes open
Visions are always private and secretive
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual vision comes from hearing God and seeing His works with eyes open
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:4 and 16 describe Balaam as one who heard the words of God and saw the vision of the Almighty with open eyes, emphasizing spiritual insight in godly leadership.

questions.question: What does Balaam’s final action in Numbers 24 teach about contentment and accepting God’s plan?
options: He returned to his place obediently after delivering God’s message
He rebelled and tried to curse Israel again
He refused to leave and stayed with Balak
questions.correctAnswer: He returned to his place obediently after delivering God’s message
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:25 shows Balaam rose up and returned to his place, illustrating submission and contentment with God’s will once the message was delivered.

hard.title: Numbers Chapter 24 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Numbers Chapter 24.

questions.question: In Numbers 24:8, Balaam describes Israel's strength using a symbolic animal. Which animal is used, and what does it signify in the ancient Near Eastern context?
questions.correctAnswer: Unicorn, symbolizing strength and majesty
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:8 uses the term 'unicorn' (Hebrew: re'em), often interpreted as a strong wild ox or a mythical horned animal, symbolizing great strength and power in the ancient Near East.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used throughout Balaam's oracles in Numbers 24 to emphasize God's sovereign blessing on Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Parable
questions.explanation: Balaam 'took up his parable' multiple times (e.g., Numbers 24:3, 24:15, 24:20), indicating the use of poetic oracles as a literary device to convey divine messages.

questions.question: How does Numbers 24:17's prophecy of a 'Star out of Jacob' and a 'Sceptre out of Israel' foreshadow Messianic expectations in later biblical texts?
options: It anticipates the coming of a royal deliverer, linked to Christ in the New Testament
It refers to a political leader in David’s time
It predicts the division of the kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: It anticipates the coming of a royal deliverer, linked to Christ in the New Testament
questions.explanation: The 'Star' and 'Sceptre' prophecy in Numbers 24:17 is traditionally interpreted as a Messianic foreshadowing, later echoed in the New Testament regarding Jesus as the royal ruler from Jacob’s lineage.

questions.question: According to Numbers 24:5-6, what natural imagery is used to describe Israel's tents, and what might this symbolize about their condition or blessing?
options: Valleys and gardens by the river, symbolizing fertility and peace
Mountains and deserts, symbolizing strength and isolation
Storms and seas, symbolizing power and chaos
Forests and caves, symbolizing protection and mystery
questions.correctAnswer: Valleys and gardens by the river, symbolizing fertility and peace
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:5-6 uses imagery of valleys and gardens by rivers to depict Israel’s flourishing and peaceful state under God’s blessing.

questions.question: What is the significance of Balaam 'falling into a trance, but having his eyes open' as mentioned in Numbers 24:4 and 24:16?
options: It indicates a prophetic vision where spiritual insight is granted despite physical awareness
It means he was unconscious and unaware
It shows he was physically asleep but speaking truth
It suggests a dream without divine origin
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates a prophetic vision where spiritual insight is granted despite physical awareness
questions.explanation: The phrase in Numbers 24:4 and 24:16 describes a prophetic state where Balaam is spiritually enlightened while still conscious, a common motif in biblical prophecy.

questions.question: In Numbers 24:9, Balaam compares Israel to a lion. What is the theological significance of this metaphor in the biblical tradition?
options: It represents Israel’s strength and invincibility under God’s protection
It denotes Israel's weakness and vulnerability
It highlights Israel’s wisdom and peace
questions.correctAnswer: It represents Israel’s strength and invincibility under God’s protection
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:9 uses the lion metaphor to emphasize Israel’s formidable power and divine blessing, a common biblical symbol for strength and kingship.

questions.question: What does Balaam mean in Numbers 24:13 when he says he cannot go beyond the commandment of the LORD to do good or bad of his own mind?
options: He must speak only what God commands, demonstrating prophetic obedience
He can choose to bless or curse as he wishes
He is free to use enchantments to curse
He is bound by Balak's wishes
questions.correctAnswer: He must speak only what God commands, demonstrating prophetic obedience
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:13 shows Balaam’s acknowledgment that his prophetic role is constrained by God's sovereign will, emphasizing divine authority over human agency.

questions.question: Which enemy nation is described as 'the first of the nations' but destined to perish forever in Numbers 24:20?
questions.correctAnswer: Amalek
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:20 identifies Amalek as the first among the nations but prophesies its ultimate destruction, highlighting its antagonism against Israel.

questions.question: According to Numbers 24:21-22, what is the fate of the Kenites, and what historical context might this reflect?
options: They dwell strongly but will be carried captive by Asshur, reflecting Assyrian conquest
questions.correctAnswer: They dwell strongly but will be carried captive by Asshur, reflecting Assyrian conquest
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:21-22 predicts the Kenites’ eventual captivity by Asshur, alluding historically to Assyrian expansion and conquest in the ancient Near East.

questions.question: What emotional reaction does Balak have toward Balaam after the latter’s repeated blessings of Israel, as described in Numbers 24:10?
questions.correctAnswer: Anger and frustration
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:10 records Balak’s anger kindled against Balaam because instead of cursing, he blessed Israel multiple times.

questions.question: How does the theme of divine sovereignty emerge in Balaam’s speeches in Numbers 24, especially regarding the blessings pronounced on Israel?
options: God’s will overrides human intentions, as Balaam cannot curse Israel
Israel’s success is due to its military might
questions.correctAnswer: God’s will overrides human intentions, as Balaam cannot curse Israel
questions.explanation: Throughout Numbers 24, Balaam’s oracles show that despite Balak’s wishes, God’s sovereign blessing on Israel prevails (e.g., Numbers 24:13).

questions.question: What is the significance of the repeated phrase 'Balaam the son of Beor hath said, and the man whose eyes are open hath said' in Numbers 24:3 and 24:15?
options: It emphasizes Balaam’s prophetic authority and visionary status
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes Balaam’s prophetic authority and visionary status
questions.explanation: The repetition in Numbers 24:3 and 24:15 serves to assert Balaam’s legitimacy as a seer with insight granted by God.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Numbers 24:7, Balaam says Israel's king shall be higher than _______, and his kingdom shall be exalted.
questions.correctAnswer: Agag
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:7 specifically mentions 'his king shall be higher than Agag,' referring to the Amalekite king, symbolizing Israel’s superiority.

questions.question: True or False: According to Numbers 24:25, after delivering his oracles, Balaam remains with Balak to continue cursing Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:25 states Balaam rose up and returned to his place, and Balak also went his way, indicating no further curses were spoken.

questions.question: What theme in Numbers 24 is reflected in later biblical texts that emphasize the blessedness of those who bless Israel and the curse on those who curse them?
questions.correctAnswer: Divine protection and covenantal blessing
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:9 introduces the theme that blessing Israel brings blessing from God, a motif echoed in scriptures like Genesis 12:3 and Romans 11.

theological.title: Numbers Chapter 24 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Numbers Chapter 24 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was Balaam's initial response upon seeing that the LORD delighted to bless Israel?
options: He set his face toward the wilderness without seeking enchantments
He sought for enchantments as usual
questions.correctAnswer: He set his face toward the wilderness without seeking enchantments
questions.explanation: According to Numbers 24:1, Balaam did not seek enchantments as before but instead set his face toward the wilderness, showing submission to God's will. This aligns with prophetic submission seen elsewhere (e.g., Isaiah 6:8, Jeremiah 1:7, Ezekiel 2:6, Acts 21:11).

questions.question: What caused the spirit of God to come upon Balaam?
options: Seeing Israel abiding in his tents according to their tribes
questions.correctAnswer: Seeing Israel abiding in his tents according to their tribes
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:2 states the spirit of God came upon Balaam as he saw Israel dwelling according to their tribes. This reflects how God's Spirit empowers prophets upon divine revelation (e.g., Numbers 11:25, Judges 6:34, 1 Samuel 10:10, Ezekiel 2:2).

questions.question: How does Balaam describe himself in his parable about Israel?
options: The man whose eyes are open and who heard the words of God
A servant seeking to curse Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The man whose eyes are open and who heard the words of God
questions.explanation: Balaam identifies himself as one who hears God's words and has open eyes (Numbers 24:3-4), emphasizing prophetic insight and divine vision, analogous to other Old Testament prophets like Isaiah (Isaiah 6:9), Ezekiel (Ezekiel 1:1), and Daniel (Daniel 7:1).

questions.question: What metaphor does Balaam use to describe Israel's tents and tabernacles?
options: As valleys spread forth and gardens by the river's side
As a fortress surrounded by enemies
questions.correctAnswer: As valleys spread forth and gardens by the river's side
questions.explanation: In Numbers 24:5-6, Israel's tents are likened to goodly tents and tabernacles as valleys and gardens by rivers, symbolizing blessing, fertility, and divine provision. This imagery aligns with Psalm 1:3 and Ezekiel 47:12 illustrating flourishing under God's blessing.

questions.question: What is said about Israel's king in Balaam's prophecy?
options: His king shall be higher than Agag, and his kingdom exalted
His king will be defeated by Moab
His king will be a foreigner
questions.correctAnswer: His king shall be higher than Agag, and his kingdom exalted
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:7 declares Israel's king will surpass Agag and have an exalted kingdom, which prophetically points to a Messianic expectation fulfilled in Christ's eternal reign (1 Samuel 15:8, Psalm 2:6-9, Daniel 7:13-14, Luke 1:32-33).

questions.question: How does Balaam describe Israel's strength as God brought them out of Egypt?
options: He hath the strength of an unicorn
He is as weak as a lamb
He is like a wandering sheep
He is like a broken reed
questions.correctAnswer: He hath the strength of an unicorn
questions.explanation: In Numbers 24:8, Israel's strength is compared to an unicorn (likely a strong wild ox), symbolizing divine empowerment and conquest. This reflects God's enabling of His people (Exodus 15:3, Psalm 22:21, Isaiah 40:29, Habakkuk 3:19).

questions.question: What blessing and curse does Balaam pronounce concerning those who bless or curse Israel?
options: Blessed is he that blesseth thee, and cursed is he that curseth thee
All who bless Israel will be destroyed
Those who curse Israel will be rewarded
Neither blessing nor curse will affect Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Blessed is he that blesseth thee, and cursed is he that curseth thee
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:9 affirms a divine principle whereby blessing Israel results in blessing and cursing Israel results in curse, reflecting God's covenant faithfulness (Genesis 12:3, Deuteronomy 7:6-9, Romans 11:28-29, Galatians 3:8).

questions.question: Why was Balak angry with Balaam according to this chapter?
options: Because Balaam blessed Israel three times instead of cursing them
Because Balaam refused to come to Moab
Because Balaam demanded more silver and gold
Because Balaam allied with Moab's enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Because Balaam blessed Israel three times instead of cursing them
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:10 records Balak's anger as Balaam blessed Israel repeatedly, showing Balaam's obedience to God over Balak's desires, emphasizing God's sovereignty over human intentions (Exodus 4:21, Jeremiah 1:10, Acts 5:29, 2 Corinthians 12:7-10).

questions.question: What reason does Balaam give for speaking only what the LORD commands?
options: He cannot go beyond the commandment of the LORD to do good or bad
He wants to gain more silver and gold
He is uncertain about God's will
questions.correctAnswer: He cannot go beyond the commandment of the LORD to do good or bad
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:13 highlights Balaam's submission to divine authority, illustrating the prophetic principle of speaking only God's word (Deuteronomy 18:18-22, Jeremiah 23:28-32, Ezekiel 3:17-21, Matthew 10:19-20).

questions.question: What messianic symbol does Balaam prophesy will come out of Jacob?
questions.correctAnswer: A Star and a Sceptre
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:17 refers to a Star and Sceptre rising from Jacob, representing the Messiah's authority and kingship, echoed in Numbers 24:17 and fulfilled in Christ (Revelation 22:16, Genesis 49:10, Psalm 2, Matthew 2:2).

questions.question: What is said about Edom and Seir in Balaam's prophecy?
options: They shall be possessions for Israel's enemies
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be possessions for Israel's enemies
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:18 states Edom and Seir will be possessions for Israel's enemies, reflecting future divine judgment and territorial shifts consistent with other prophetic oracles (Obadiah 1:10-14, Ezekiel 35, Joel 3:19, Malachi 1:3).

questions.question: What is the final destiny of Amalek according to Balaam's prophecy?
options: He will repent and be blessed
He will form a lasting kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: He shall perish forever
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:20 declares Amalek's end as eternal destruction, consistent with the divine judgment theme on Amalek throughout Scripture (Exodus 17:14, Deuteronomy 25:17-19, 1 Samuel 15:2-3, Hebrews 10:30).

questions.question: How does Balaam describe the Kenites' dwelling place?
options: Strong and nested in a rock
questions.correctAnswer: Strong and nested in a rock
questions.explanation: In Numbers 24:21, the Kenites' home is described as strong and secure like a nest in a rock, symbolizing stability and protection, which is a biblical image of God's refuge (Psalm 18:2, Psalm 31:2, Isaiah 32:2, Matthew 7:24-25).

questions.question: What impending event does Balaam predict concerning the Kenites?
options: They shall be wasted until Asshur carries them captive
They will become kings of Moab
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be wasted until Asshur carries them captive
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:22 foretells the Kenites’ destruction and captivity by Asshur, indicating God's sovereign control over nations and judgment (Isaiah 10:5-6, 2 Kings 17:3-6, Jeremiah 25:9, Habakkuk 1:5).

questions.question: What is the reaction Balaam expresses about God's actions in his final parable?
options: Alas, who shall live when God doeth this!
questions.correctAnswer: Alas, who shall live when God doeth this!
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:23 expresses awe and fear regarding God's impending judgment, highlighting the holiness and justice of God (Exodus 15:11, Isaiah 6:5, Habakkuk 3:2, Revelation 15:4).

questions.question: What future event involving ships from Chittim does Balaam prophesy?
options: They will afflict Asshur and Eber, causing their destruction
They will bring peace to Moab
They will establish trade with Israel
They will be destroyed by Israel
questions.correctAnswer: They will afflict Asshur and Eber, causing their destruction
questions.explanation: Numbers 24:24 predicts ships from Chittim will afflict Asshur and Eber, symbolizing divine judgment through foreign powers, consistent with prophetic themes of nations as instruments of God's justice (Jeremiah 25:22, Ezekiel 27:6, Isaiah 23:1-14, Revelation 18).
